Greatest common divisor of a finite set

type:
{α : Type u_1} →
  {β : Type u_2} → [inst : CancelCommMonoidWithZero α] → [inst : NormalizedGCDMonoid α] → Finset β → (β → α) → α
name: Finset.gcd
docString: Greatest common divisor of a finite set

For all integers x and k (with k != 0), k * ⌊x / k⌋ ≤ x.

name: Int.mul_ediv_self_le
docString: For all integers x and k (with k != 0), k * ⌊x / k⌋ ≤ x.

The theorem `Int.gcd_dvd_left` states that for any two integers `a` and `b`, the greatest common divisor (gcd) of `a` and `b` divides `a`. This is written in the Lean theorem prover as `↑(Int.gcd a b) ∣ a`, where `Int.gcd a b` computes the gcd of `a` and `b`, the `↑` operator converts that gcd from a natural number to an integer, and `∣` represents the "divides" relation. In mathematical terms, if $gcd(a, b) = d$, then $d | a$.

type: ∀ {a b : ℤ}, ↑(a.gcd b) ∣ a
name: Int.gcd_dvd_left
docString: The theorem `Int.gcd_dvd_left` states that for any two integers `a` and `b`, the greatest common divisor (gcd) of `a` and `b` divides `a`. This is written in the Lean theorem prover as `↑(Int.gcd a b) ∣ a`, where `Int.gcd a b` computes the gcd of `a` and `b`, the `↑` operator converts that gcd from a natural number to an integer, and `∣` represents the "divides" relation. In mathematical terms, if $gcd(a, b) = d$, then $d | a$.

The greatest common divisor (gcd) of two positive natural numbers,
viewed as positive natural number.

name: PNat.gcd
docString:
The greatest common divisor (gcd) of two positive natural numbers,
viewed as positive natural number.

If the greatest common divisor of each element and a natural number `x` in a finite set is 1, then the greatest common divisor of their product and `x` is also 1.

type: ∀ {ι : Type u_1} {t : Finset ι} {s : ι → ℕ} {x : ℕ}, (∀ i ∈ t, (s i).Coprime x) → (t.prod fun i => s i).Coprime x
name: Nat.Coprime.prod_left
docString: If the greatest common divisor of each element and a natural number `x` in a finite set is 1, then the greatest common divisor of their product and `x` is also 1.

This theorem states that for all natural numbers `m` and `n`, if `m` divides `n` (denoted as `m ∣ n`), then the greatest common divisor (gcd) of `m` and `n` is `m` itself. In other words, if a number `m` is a divisor of another number `n`, then `m` is the largest number that can divide both `m` and `n` without leaving a remainder.

type: ∀ {m n : ℕ}, m ∣ n → m.gcd n = m
name: Nat.gcd_eq_left
docString: This theorem states that for all natural numbers `m` and `n`, if `m` divides `n` (denoted as `m ∣ n`), then the greatest common divisor (gcd) of `m` and `n` is `m` itself. In other words, if a number `m` is a divisor of another number `n`, then `m` is the largest number that can divide both `m` and `n` without leaving a remainder.

Greatest common divisor of a multiset

type: {α : Type u_1} → [inst : CancelCommMonoidWithZero α] → [inst : NormalizedGCDMonoid α] → Multiset α → α
name: Multiset.gcd
docString: Greatest common divisor of a multiset

The greatest common divisor between two elements.

type: {α : Type u_2} → [inst : CancelCommMonoidWithZero α] → [self : GCDMonoid α] → α → α → α
name: GCDMonoid.gcd
docString: The greatest common divisor between two elements.

Nonzero divisors have valuation greater than zero.

type:
∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] [inst_2 : IsDedekindDomain R]
  (v : IsDedekindDomain.HeightOneSpectrum R) (x : ↥(nonZeroDivisors R)),
  0 < IsDedekindDomain.HeightOneSpectrum.intValuationDef v ↑x
name: IsDedekindDomain.HeightOneSpectrum.int_valuation_zero_le
docString: Nonzero divisors have valuation greater than zero.

The divisors of a product of natural numbers are the pointwise product of the divisors of the
factors.

type: ∀ (m n : ℕ), Nat.divisors (m * n) = Nat.divisors m * Nat.divisors n
name: Nat.divisors_mul
docString:
The divisors of a product of natural numbers are the pointwise product of the divisors of the
factors.

If an integer with larger absolute value divides an integer, it is
zero.

type: ∀ {a b : ℤ}, a ∣ b → Int.natAbs b < Int.natAbs a → b = 0
name: Int.eq_zero_of_dvd_of_natAbs_lt_natAbs
docString:
If an integer with larger absolute value divides an integer, it is
zero.

The GCD is a divisor of the first element.

type: ∀ {α : Type u_2} [inst : CancelCommMonoidWithZero α] [self : GCDMonoid α] (a b : α), gcd a b ∣ a
name: GCDMonoid.gcd_dvd_left
docString: The GCD is a divisor of the first element.

If `ξ` is an integer, all its convergents equal `ξ`.

type: ∀ {ξ : ℤ} (n : ℕ), Real.convergent (↑ξ) n = ↑ξ
name: Real.convergent_of_int
docString: If `ξ` is an integer, all its convergents equal `ξ`.

For nonzero integers `a` and `b`, `gcd a b` is the smallest positive natural number that can be
written in the form `a * x + b * y` for some pair of integers `x` and `y`

type: ∀ {a b : ℤ}, a ≠ 0 → IsLeast {n | 0 < n ∧ ∃ x y, ↑n = a * x + b * y} (Int.gcd a b)
name: Int.gcd_least_linear
docString:
For nonzero integers `a` and `b`, `gcd a b` is the smallest positive natural number that can be
written in the form `a * x + b * y` for some pair of integers `x` and `y`

For `d ∣ n`, the totient of `n/d` equals the number of values `k < n` such that `gcd n k = d`

type: ∀ {n d : ℕ}, d ∣ n → Nat.totient (n / d) = (Finset.filter (fun k => Nat.gcd n k = d) (Finset.range n)).card
name: Nat.totient_div_of_dvd
docString: For `d ∣ n`, the totient of `n/d` equals the number of values `k < n` such that `gcd n k = d`

Any common divisor of both elements is a divisor of the GCD.

type: ∀ {α : Type u_2} [inst : CancelCommMonoidWithZero α] [self : GCDMonoid α] {a b c : α}, a ∣ c → a ∣ b → a ∣ gcd c b
name: GCDMonoid.dvd_gcd
docString: Any common divisor of both elements is a divisor of the GCD.

If a solution has `x > 1`, then `d` is positive.

type: ∀ {d : ℤ} {a : Pell.Solution₁ d}, 1 < Pell.Solution₁.x a → 0 < d
name: Pell.Solution₁.d_pos_of_one_lt_x
docString: If a solution has `x > 1`, then `d` is positive.

For any `y < 1` and any positive `x`, there exists `n : ℕ` with `y ^ n < x`.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : LinearOrderedSemifield α] [inst_1 : Archimedean α] [inst_2 : ExistsAddOfLE α] {x y : α},
  0 < x → y < 1 → ∃ n, y ^ n < x
name: exists_pow_lt_of_lt_one
docString: For any `y < 1` and any positive `x`, there exists `n : ℕ` with `y ^ n < x`.

The integers modulo `n : ℕ`.

type: ℕ → Type
name: ZMod
docString: The integers modulo `n : ℕ`.

Every nonzero natural number has a unique prime factorization

type: Set.InjOn Nat.factorization {x | x ≠ 0}
name: Nat.factorization_inj
docString: Every nonzero natural number has a unique prime factorization

Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same divisors.

name: Nat.dvd_left_iff_eq
docString: Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same divisors.

No zero divisors.

type: ∀ {α : Type u_2} [self : CanonicallyOrderedCommSemiring α] {a b : α}, a * b = 0 → a = 0 ∨ b = 0
name: CanonicallyOrderedCommSemiring.eq_zero_or_eq_zero_of_mul_eq_zero
docString: No zero divisors.

`A[x]` is a fractional ideal for every integral `x`.

type:
∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing R] (S : Submonoid R) {P : Type u_2} [inst_1 : CommRing P] [inst_2 : Algebra R P]
  [loc : IsLocalization S P] (x : P), IsIntegral R x → IsFractional S (Subalgebra.toSubmodule (Algebra.adjoin R {x}))
name: FractionalIdeal.isFractional_adjoin_integral
docString: `A[x]` is a fractional ideal for every integral `x`.

If `x` is a Liouville number, then for any `n`, for infinitely many denominators `b` there
exists a numerator `a` such that `x ≠ a / b` and `|x - a / b| < 1 / b ^ n`.

type: ∀ {x : ℝ}, Liouville x → ∀ (n : ℕ), ∃ᶠ (b : ℕ) in Filter.atTop, ∃ a, x ≠ ↑a / ↑b ∧ |x - ↑a / ↑b| < 1 / ↑b ^ n
name: Liouville.frequently_exists_num
docString:
If `x` is a Liouville number, then for any `n`, for infinitely many denominators `b` there
exists a numerator `a` such that `x ≠ a / b` and `|x - a / b| < 1 / b ^ n`.
